coplan.title: David B. Coplan Biography
coplan.content:
David B. Coplan is Professor and Chair of Social Anthropology at the University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa.

Born in the USA, he has a B.A (Hons) from Williams College 1970; M.A. University of Ghana, 1974; M.A. Indiana University, 1976; Ph.D. Indiana University 1980. Dr. Coplan has carried out fieldwork in Lesotho, Swaziland, South Africa, Ghana, and the United States.

He has also held visiting appointments at institutions as diverse as the University of Basel, École des Hautes Études Sciences Sociales (Paris), and the University of Cape Town among others. He acted as the Chief Researcher for the “Mobilising Culture and Heritage for Nation Building” in South Africa’s Arts and Culture Department and worked as an ethnographic research consultant for the University of Pennsylvania Museum and International Library of African Music.

Professor's Coplan research interests include African ethnology, history, and theory of anthropology, performing arts, urban anthropology, culture change, social organization, and border studies. Today he is Prosor Emeritus, Social Anthropology, University of the Witwatersrand.

frida.title: Frida Kahlo's Biography
frida.content:
Frida Kahlo was born in 1907 and died in 1954 in Coyoacán, Mexico City. Her full name was Magdalena Carmen Frida Kahlo Calderón.

She studied at the German School and the National Preparatory School in Mexico City. In 1925, she suffered a tragic accident, the consequences of which endured until her death. During a long convalescence, Frida began to paint her face by copying it from a mirror mounted on the canopy of her bed. At first, she was a realist and painted portraits of family and friends, and also flowers. Later, though, because of the intensity of her feelings and her shattered body, she increasingly painted herself in dreamlike, sometimes brutal contexts. Some of her work has even been associated with surrealist tendencies because of its introspective character.

In 1929, she married Diego Rivera, whom she divorced in 1940 and remarried a year later. She taught painting at the Escuela de Artes Plasticas and was a member of the Seminary of Mexican Culture. In 1938, she mounted her first solo exhibition at the Julien Levy Gallery in New York. Her works were included in the 1939 "Mexique" Exhibition, presented at the Renou et Colle Gallery in Paris, as well as in other group shows presented in Mexico throughout her life.

She participated in the International Exhibition of Surrealism organised in 1940 at the Gallery of Modern Art in Mexico City. Important institutions such as the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Georges Pompidou Centre in Paris house some of her works.

leon.title: Leon Botha’s Biography
leon.content:
Leon Botha was born in Cape Town, South Africa where he lived until his death. He was diagnosed with progeria at the age of 4. While he had no formal education in the arts, after graduating, he became a full time painter doing commissioned work.

In 2005, he successfully underwent surgery to prevent heart attacks due to progeria-related atherosclerosis.

In January 2007, Botha held his first exhibition entitled "Liquid Sword; I am HipHop". It portrayed Hip Hop culture as a way of life and was opened by Mr Fat of the South African Hip Hop group Brasse Vannie Kaap.

In March 2009, he opened his second exhibition featuring aspects of his life. When asked if the title ‘Liquid Swords; Slices of Lemon’ referred to the saying ‘If life gives you lemons, make lemonade’, Botha denied it, adding ‘Lemons? I slice them and serve them.’

In January 2010 he held the first exhibition of ‘Who Am I?... Transgressions’, a collaborative photography work with Gordon Clark at the João Ferreira Gallery in Cape Town. About the exhibition, Botha stated ‘First I am, like you, a spiritual being. Then I am a human being and this part of the human being, which is the body, has a condition.’

Botha also practised deejaying and toasting under the name DJ Solarize. He was featured alongside Watkin Tudor Jones (also known as Ninja), in Die Antwoord's Enter The Ninja video.

In November 2010, Botha suffered a stroke. He died of cardiac arrest a day after his 26th birthday, in 2011.

welcome.title: Welcome
welcome.text: The UNAM-South Africa Mexican Studies Centre welcomes you to this space dedicated to disability awareness at the university. The project’s goal is to compare conditions for disabled students in Mexico and South Africa, specifically between the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) and The University of the Witwatersrand (Wits). Here you will find materials from our disability seminar entitled ‘Mexico and South Africa: A multidisciplinary approach to disability’ dedicated to showcasing disability-inclusive improvements in university facilities and their educational processes.

south_africa.title: South African Context
south_africa.text: Apartheid in South Africa was marked not only by political struggles but social activism too. One focused on securing recognition of the disabled. Since then, the South African government has created specialized departments to ensure respect for the human rights of minorities, including people with disabilities. The mission, however, is far from over. Wits University’s outstanding Disability Rights Unit (DRU) is responsible for supporting students with disabilities in both academic and non-academic activities and runs a constant information campaign about the difficulties disabled students encounter in order to raise awareness, both within and without the university.

mexico.title: Mexican Context
mexico.text: Did you know that according to INEGI data, in its 2020 census, 4.9% of Mexico’s population suffers from some type of disability? The most recent data shows that 50% are women. In Mexico, disability is also a relevant issue that concerns the government, as evinced in the Political Constitution of the United States of Mexico, in its articles 1 (No discrimination), and 4 (economic support for disabled people by law). UNAM, as Mexico’s most prestigious academic institution, finds itself obliged to seek means of improving the access of the disabled to quality education, fostering inclusion, and ensuring the human rights of all students.

general.title: General Context
general.text:
Did you know that 15% of the world’s population suffers from some type of disability?

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines the disabled as ‘people who suffer some health problem (for example, brain paralysis, Down syndrome, or depression)’ and disability as ‘personal and environmental agents (for example, negative attitudes, inadequate public facilities, or limited social support)’.


This project explores disabled students’ experience within the university context, specifically in academia, culture, and sports. The icons below indicate the type of disability each event addresses, so we invite you to learn more by hovering over them to view the various events we have prepared for you.

videos.title: Learn about the history of disability inclusion in South Africa and about the Paralympics. Also, don't miss the differences between Mexican and South African sign language.

discussions.title: Discussions
discussions.description: UNAM-South Africa, in collaboration with the University of the Witwatersrand’s Disability Rights Unit, the Committee of Assistance for Disabled Persons (CAD, UNAM), the Assistance Unit for Disabled Persons (UNAPDI, UNAM), and the Unit of Computing and Information and Communication Technologies (DGTIC, UNAM), extends a cordial invitation to Disability Seminars 2022, Mexico and South Africa: A multidisciplinary approach to disability. The inaugural event and keynote speeches, Overcoming the Challenges of Disability in Higher Education, will take place next Tuesday, September 6 at 16h00 (South Africa time). The event* will be streamed live on the UNAM South Africa Facebook page. If you would like to access the seminar in English through Zoom, please register here. * This event is free and includes South African sign language interpreter.

visual.title: Visual impairment
visual.description: A condition directly affecting image perception partially or totally.

hearing.title: Hearing impairment
hearing.description: The absence, decrease, or loss of the ability to hear somewhere in the hearing system.

motor.title: Motor disability
motor.description: An alteration of the motor system that makes it difficult or impossible to develop capacities that allow participation in day-to-day activities.

intellectual.title: Intellectual disability
intellectual.description: Significant limitations both in the structure of reasoned thought and adaptive behavior.
